events.name: Advanced (elastic)search for your legacy application
events.description:
Hello everyone!

It's time for our last session before a well deserved summer break!

Please note that the event will not take place in our usual venue, but in Computer Futures offices, so check the address.
They will also kindly provide food and beverages so you won't starve during the evening!

The Poster:

As usual, share this event with your friends & colleagues by hanging our poster in the coffee corner: https://app.box.com/s/1mvl67ll3esmcrsut3fvzil8a2vtyyma

Abstract:

How do you mix SQL and NoSQL worlds without starting a messy revolution?

This live coding talk will show you how to add Elasticsearch to your legacy application without changing all your current development habits. Your application will have suddenly have advanced search features, all without the need to write complex SQL code!

David will start from a RestX, Hibernate and Postgresql/MySQL based application and will add a complete integration of Elasticsearch, all live from the stage during his presentation.

About the Speaker:

David Pilato discovered Elasticsearch project in 2011. After contributed to the project and created open source plugins for it, David joined elastic the company in 2013 where he is Developer and Evangelist. He also created and still actively managing the French spoken language User Group. At elastic, he mainly worked on Elasticsearch source code, specifically on open-source plugins. In his free time, he likes talking about elasticsearch in conferences or in companies (Brown Bag Lunches). He is also author of FSCrawler project which helps to index your pdf, open office, whatever documents in elasticsearch using Apache Tika behind the scene.

Our sponsors:

* Computer Futures is a well established IT recruiting and contracting company.
They are looking for new ways to find talents by putting people first.
With a proven track record in IT recruitment, we enjoy success within all sectors and business types. From single job vacancies to large-scale projects, our proficiency in providing exceptional professionals across the board has carved our reputation as a secure and significant supplier partner. A big thank you for their support!

* Arexo is a human-sized IT consulting company, currently looking for new hires.
Arexo is more than happy to be sponsoring BruJUG.
Hopefully this will help BruJUG to provide even more greatness to the community.
We'll meet soon, but you can already learn more about us at arexo.be

events.name: Working with outsourced content
events.description:
We'll have some time for networking, followed by a talk.

Title: Outsourcing: Working with content from other companies

Outsourcing is big business and growing. Companies are increasingly outsourcing product development and services to reduce costs and focus on their core business. As writers, we’re familiar with companies contracting out technical communication work. However, my presentation will discuss outsourcing product development and manufacturing and what impact this can have on in-house technical communication. What challenges can technical writers face when working with content developed by another company? I’ll look at such topics as content quality, legal issues, localization, tools, terminology management, and working with teams that are dispersed globally and across different companies and cultures with a focus on working with Chinese suppliers.

Presenter:
Jennifer O'Neill is a Senior Technical Writer at UTC Fire & Security in Diegem, Belgium.

events.name: Greenfield Continuous Deployment using Kubernetes and Gitlab (w/SocratesBE)
events.description:
Dear Craftsmen, DevOps, and friends,

In cooperation with Socrates BE (https://www.meetup.com/socratesbe/), Wemanity has the pleasure of welcoming Kris Hofmans. Kris is a passionate Software engineer who met equally passionate people and founded Triple D to Design, Develop, Deploy software together. When he isn’t spending time with the family you can probably find him coding.

Setting up your applications to automatically and continuously deploy might have caused you headaches in the past. But these days it’s becoming a lot easier to get a deployment pipeline up and running. Using the recently released rancher 2 we’Il create a fresh kubernetes cluster. Then a spring boot application will be generated by start.spring.io that will be pushed to gitlab. Gitlab will add some magic autodevops dust to the project. After the dust settles there will be a running application, with dynamic review environments, and detailed metrics.

This session will be a combination of a presentation explaining how this works and a live demo setting everything up from scratch. Yes, you read it correctly. Kubernetes cluster, an application and CD allowing an environment per branch all setup during this session.

A sharing session will take place afterward with pizzas and a few beers to discuss and share :-)

Hope to see you there!

The Wemanity Team

events.name: An evening walk
events.description:
This time I organise an evening walk across the Sonian Wood (Forêt de Soignes), Arboretum and fields around Brussels on Friday evening.
We will take a train to Groenendaal where we will start walking across an area of the forest that is not very well known. Later, we will explore the Arboretum of Tervuren when nightfall comes. This is an area where you can see some deers and foxes time to time.
We will come back to Montgoméry with tram 44 at almost midnight.
I think it is a better idea to use the common small torches (if necessary) than headlamps, in order to prevent light pollution. Headlamps dazzle a lot, mainly when you talk to someone.
Weather will be good. Warm temperature and no rain. Length of the walk: no more than 18 km.
Train SB3969. Schuman 7.38 pm, Luxembourg 7.42, Etterbeek 7.46, Boitsfort 7.49, Groenendaal 7.53.
Drinks, snacks and good mood are advisable.
By signing up to this activity you accept that you participate under your own responsability. Guides are volunteers and are not responsible for the safety of the attendees to the activity.

events.name: Workshop | Building Tech for Diversity & Inclusion
events.description:
Diversity is key to your success as a technologist.

The facts are simple: the technology you build should represent your users. It is not only important to have a diverse team of tech talents, it is also important to take your users into account when you build it.

If you're nodding your head, this workshop is for you. Keep reading.

The Bacchao Project, Open Knowledge Belgium and BeCentral are happy to bring you a hands-on & insightful workshop called "Building Tech for Diversity and Inclusion".

Tickets: https://workshop-building-tech-for-diversity-inclusion.eventbrite.co.uk. Meetup RSVP is not enough to secure your spot, please don't forget to get your tickets.

The workshop will take the participants around the fundamentals of designing technology that takes the diversity of its intended uses into account and includes these users with active participation. It's designed for developers & funders who want to rethink their technology.

During the full day hands-on workshop, you will look into "Manual for building technology for diversity and inclusion" written by The Bachchao Project. The manual is published under open license and is available on Github: https://github.com/thebachchaoproject/Manual-to-build-tech-for-diversity-and-Inclusion/blob/master/BuildingTechforDiversityandInclusion101.pdf.

Firstly, you will deep dive into everyday apps and technologies that could be built by the participants or used widely and document how to improve them. Secondly, you will take these learnings into consideration to reflect on your own project.

About the speaker

Chinmayi is a computer science engineer by qualification and the founder of The Bachchao Project, a community that works on the intersection of gender and technology. She previously worked as an engineer with Nokia and founded Saakshin, a software services start-up in Bengaluru, India.

Over the past four years, Chinmayi has been a pivotal part of several civil society projects, which involve building technology communities as well as creating technological solutions to address gender and humanitarian issues. She supports the technical and policy needs of numerous groups and organisations such as Internews, Safecity, Breakthrough, Flone, Geeks Without Bounds, and Bailancho Saad.

We want our workshop to be an event anyone can join. Price shouldn't be a barrier. Let us know why you really want to participate and apply for a "Hacker Ticket" to get your ticket at a discounted price (15€). Apply via this form for a Hacker Ticket: https://goo.gl/forms/RhaCfapmyHEHON2h1.

events.name: Introduction to audio electronics (1/4)
events.description:
Introduction to audio-electronics

This four-piece seminar-series is meant to teach some of the underlying principles of audio-amplification, frequency-filtering and signal-processing that apply to amplifiers, guitar stompboxes and microphone preamps. During this course you will be introduced to the fundamental building blocks of analog circuits (resistors, capacitors, transistors and op-amps), learn how to distinguish circuit-building blocks and how to apply some simple calculators for frequency-filtering. Lastly, we'll dissect some schematics to understand the function of each and every component.
The workshop will conclude with a 'practical' involving the building of your own DIY distortion- or fuzz pedal, for which kits will be supplied. The supply of these is limited, so make sure you sign up timely.

-Basic knowledge of electronics is useful, but I'll try to accommodate all attendees
-Some mathematics might be introduced, but they'll be approached from a pragmatists' perspective

Part 1. (Wednesday 19:00 - 21:00 --- 13/06/2018---)
We all know what sound is, but what does it look like in its electronic form? We'll see how a speaker works and how it is able to produce sound. Then we’ll look at various waveforms (sines, square waves and other sinusoids) and the translation between the ‘frequency-domain’ and ‘time-domain’. When the crowd is math-savvy we could try a Taylor-expansion of a square wave. Otherwise we’ll indulge in the knowledge that Fourier-transformations give us.
With our knowledge of waveforms, we will assess various types of signal distortion. Some more pleasant than others.

Part 2. (Wednesday 19:00 - 21:00 --- 20/06/2018---)
Time to get into some real electronics here. We’ll be introduced to the basic drawing elements and shapes of circuits and take a look at the principal components of analog circuits: Resistors, capacitors, diodes and transistors. With the latter, some basic equations will (have to) be introduced / recapitulated.
With our knowledge of peripheral components, we’ll introduce the Operational Amplifier and review the usage of these so-called OPAMPS in audio circuits.

Part 3. (Wednesday 19:00 - 21:00 --- 27/06/2018---)
This course we’ll look at the filters we could think up with the knowledge of our last course. Resistor-capacitor networks will be discussed, and basic calculations for cutoff-frequencies will be demonstrated. Secondly, fundamental building blocks of audio circuits are on the program: Buffer stages, gain stages, clipping stages, frequency filters and power supplies .
Part 4. (Wednesday 19:00 - 21:00 --- 4/07/2018---)
Our last theoretical escapade will be the analysis of real-life circuits. With the knowledge of previous lectures, we should be able to dissect a variety of well-known and interesting real life circuits. A selection of circuits will be up for discussion, depending on the preferences of the attendees. If time permits, we’ll draw out the good ‘ole oscilloscope and tinker with some breadboarded circuits to see- and hear the consequences of our modifications.

Praxis in practice (Saturday 12:00 onwards --- 7/07/2018---)
If there is any participants left after this fourfold technical torture, allow me to remind you that nothing tastes (or sounds) quite as good as the fruits of your own labour. Three types of kits will be available for this session: A distortion pedal , a fuzz pedal and a third yet-to-be developed secret kit. They’ll consist of a Pre-drilled enclosure, a PCB, all peripheral components and a solid explanation of how-to-put-the-thing-together. This will def be an afternoon session, and I’ll be there to assist everyone in their soldering-and-assembly process. To pay for the enclosure, pots and the PCB-manufacturing, a fee of € 35,- will be charged. The three circuits available are HSBXL-only and loosely based on the sickest sounds the streets have to offer. All hail King Buzzo, Dimebag Amen.

events.name: Moving to Microservice Architecture + Bonus: GCP certificate exam overview
events.description:
We'll bring you the story of how Vente-Exclusive.com moved from a big monolith to a microservices architecture. You'll get some insights and war stories, but we'll also give you a view on the architecture.

The new architecture enables rapid iterations, easy deployment and real time insights for our business analysts. We'll touch a lot of GCP technologies like Kubernetes Engine, Pub/Sub, DataFlow, BigTable, BigQuery to name but a few. It also shows you that having most of your services developed on Microsoft .NET Core isn't an issue running on the Google Cloud Platform.

Hopefully these insights will help you when you start building your next generation platform. Be sure to stick around for the ask us anything after session along with some pizza and drinks.

The story is brought by Nico Francois (Lead architect) and Alex Van Boxel (Cloud/Big Data Architect).

Bonus: Niels Buekers will give you an insight on the new Google Cloud certification with some sample questions. He will give you some pointers on how to study for the exam and talk about some of the possible pitfalls.

events.name: Hands on with TensorFlowJS
events.description:
GDG Brussels and VRLab Brussels have decided to join forces to learn more about TensorFlowJS, the machine learning library for the Web from Google.
In this meetup we will get familiar with the library, then do some exercices with it, and then finally end on a Q&A session and conclusion.

Agenda:
17h30: Doors are open, come on over
18h00: Introduction to TensorFlowJS
18h30: Hands on exercises
20h30: Conclusion
21h00: The End

Do not forget to bring your computer for the hands on, and your smile and enthusiasm.

NOTE: We are starting the talks at 18:00, with the doors opening at 17:30, so please arrive on time to ensure we run on schedule.

Thank you so much to DigitYser to help us host this event.

See you there in number!

Cheers

events.name: Talk with Stéphanie Fellen, Founder & CEO at Made & More
events.description:
Do you know where the t-shirt you're wearing comes from ? If you look at the label, does it give you any indication on the people who made it and their work conditions ? Most clothing items don't. But if you shop at Made & More, it's a different story. Their labels have a QR code which takes you to videos, pictures and explanations on the origins and the stories of what you’re wearing.

Made & More is a belgian sustainable fashion brand created by Stéphanie Fellen, whom we are very pleased to welcome for our new Le Wagon talk. She launched her own business online and went through the struggles many entrepreneurs face, including filing for bankruptcy. But hard work paid off, and her vision became reality. Her clothes are made with total transparency regarding who made the garments, and with respect for the people and the environnement. The brand is in line with circular economy vision.

She will take us through her entrepreneurial journey, discuss crowdfunding and the use of technology to improve the traceability of fashion.

6:15PM > Doors opening
6:30PM > Start of Le Wagon Talk, be there on time! :-)

It’s free, but registration is mandatory : https://bit.ly/2yoS2uT

events.name: How to hire and manage remote teams?
events.description:
Hiring is a big step in the life of every business, and hiring remotely is an opportunity to do so in a cost-effective way, using a wide pool of talent. This trend is only about to get stronger, and mastering it is a vital skill for every business owner.

**** Please register using this link, spaces are limited: webinar.startupblink.com (http://webinar.startupblink.com/) ****

This lecture is based on the experiences of Eli David, the co-founder of StartupBlink, a global map of the startup ecosystem with tens of thousands of registered users and 70 meetup chapters around the world, featured in dozens of articles including Forbes and Business Insider. Eli is also the co-founder of LingoLearn, an online language school with hundreds of students.

Eli is a digital nomad since 2010 who has lived/traveled in more than 60 countries and is constantly changing locations every few months. More on this lifestyle can be read in Eli’s Blog&Podcast- BecomeNomad (http://www.becomenomad.com/), and in this CNN article (http://money.cnn.com/interactive/technology/15-questions-with-eli-david/index.html).

What you'll learn in this great lecture:

- The best techniques to hire and manage freelancers from around the world to help you grow your business.

- A discussion about trends in hiring platforms, and how to manage them wisely (e.g. Upwork).

- Eli’s lifestyle of constant travel pushed him to specialize in working with online teams, and he will share his experience and insights about managing a remote workspace.

- There will also be plenty of time for Q&A's, so get your questions ready!

**** Please register using this link, spaces are limited: webinar.startupblink.com (http://webinar.startupblink.com/) ****

Looking for a cowoking space, to make remote work more efficient?
Our partners at WeWork are offering up to 15% discount in over 240 coworking spaces around the world, exclusive to StartupBlink members. This discount will only available during the next few weeks, so you should hurry up and claim it here! http://wework.startupblink.com/

Are you building a hardware product?
We know it’s hard at the beginning with the limited resources startup have. StartupBlink’s partnership with ANSYS Startup Program is here to help! The program allows startups to get access to the world’s leading simulation tool to help you build an amazing virtual prototype. Find out if you’re one of the lucky eligible startups here (https://ansys.startupblink.com/)

events.name: Speaker training in partnership with Devoxx and IBM
events.description:
Want to become an international rock star speaker?

We're running a speaker clinic/training for those of you keen to submit a talk to a conference, but looking for guidance on where to get started.

We will cover the basics, giving you some simple guidelines to help prepare you for your first presentation, as well as some insider tips to consider when submitting your talk ideas.

The most important thing you should get from this session is probably how you’re going to handle having a sea of faces staring expectantly at you when you take to the stage.

This session is aimed at both audience and NOVICE speakers - people who have never done it before, or have limited experience with presenting, and want to take that first step.

Come to this session if:

• You'd like to present at a local User Group event, but you're not confident enough yet
• You're wondering if you could present at Devoxx or another conference
• You want practical help getting started with public speaking
• You're simply curious about what it's like

This is very much an introductory session (although more confident speakers are welcome), and will focus on your skills as a presenter, not the mechanics of building a slide deck or talk.

Beyond the event we'll help to connect you with a mentor who can guide you all the way through to your first lightning talk/evening presentation to your first conference presentation.

AGENDA

[masked]h Walk in and drinks

[masked]h Welcome and speaker tips & tricks (by Stephan Janssen)

[masked]h give your 5 mins talk and get feedback from the mentors (split in two groups)

[masked]h pizza break (and rehearse)

[masked]h do your talk and get a video recording

[masked]h closing

Partners

IBM - Thanks to IBM for supporting the initiative and providing the venue for us and the drinks & pizza!

Devoxx - Every year the Devoxx Family welcomes over 17,000 developers to events in Belgium, France, UK, Poland, Morocco & the Ukraine. In 2018 Devoxx Belgium is looking to fill 200 speaker sessions!

events.description:
Connect Instantly - Hit it off with anyone in 60 seconds
Hosted by Francesca A. Fata

Remember that person who made a neutral impression on you at that event last week? – Nobody ever does.

People live and die by snap judgements they make about others within 60 seconds (at most!) of meeting someone new.

*********************************************************************************

In this workshop, we will focus on developing the skills that make people like you instantly, because a neutral impression is as good as never meeting anyone at all.

*********************************************************************************

Imagine how much better and more fun your life would be if you could hit it off instantly with people - anywhere, anytime:

☀ a whole new bunch of friends to hang out with,

☀ new clients who feel drawn to you,

☀ more meaningful experiences in the dating world,

and the list goes on.

Instant connections don’t have to feel contrived, fake or forced though. You don’t need to manipulate people or plaster a fake smile on your face for someone to like you.

Sincerity is actually one of the main drivers for likability!

All you need to do is to simply train yourself in the art of connecting instantly.

☟ ☟ ☟ ☟ ☟ ☟

More about that on 20 June!

Register here: https://bit.ly/2JgB9Yf

See you soon ☺

About Francesca:
https://www.linkedin.com/in/francescaafata/

events.name: Coder Dojo: Chat application with Reason React and GraphQL!
events.description:
Iwan (Maxim Valcke), one of the most active Reason core contributors, will join us to talk about Reason and will help mentoring this evening. We are very thankful to have him!

In this Dojo, we will build a Chat Application with Reason React and GraphQL!

We will focus on the client by writing a React application written in Reason.
You will all connect to the same GraphQL server to build a Chat Application. We will start with simple GraphQL queries and mutations and then use the power of GraphQL Subscriptions to create a real time Chat Application!!

Schedule
6:30: Pizza's & editor setup
7:00: Talk from Iwan (Maxim Valcke)
7:15: Live coding Greg Van Der Auwermeulen & Hans Scheuren to show the usage of GraphQL with Reason
7:30: Everyone starts coding the Chat Application in small groups
9:00: Demo of a working app, questions, feedback

What is Reason?
Reason is a programming language.
Reason is not made for building websites specifically, it is made to write - software that scales!
You can write anything with Reason and run it everywhere:
Reason is a 'language' you could transpile to Javascript to build a website
React Native application or a NodeJS backend, but you can also use it to transpile to native code to write a game for example.

For whom is this event?
Developers! Enthousiasts! Javascript, GraphQL, React, front end, backend, functional, ... interest!

Be sure to bring your laptop and to have :
- Stable version of NodeJS installed
- Editor Setup (We can help you to set it up while eating pizza too)
- Reason installed

Hope to see you there,
Hans, Iwan & Greg

events.name: Work Jam + Networking
events.description:
Working alone is no fun...

Solution? Work Jam! Get things done and meet like-minded people in a session of working together.

When and Where?

Bring either a laptop, iPad, notebook or whatever you need to complete your tasks. If you arrive first, please write a comment below about where you're sitting and how to identify you (e.g. shirt color). If you don't see a comment, you are the first person, so post one.

What?

25 minutes work sessions ("Pomodoro Technique") with 5 minutes of break between each. We'll have 4 sessions in total, which sums up to 2 hours. Optional to continue after that until the last person gives up!

Why?

Working together is proved to boost your productivity. It will also create the accountability as you will declare your goals and results for each session. Also, meeting new people face to face while working together will connect you to potential team members, clients and friends. It's a powerful mix of focused work with networking in short breaks.

How?

Just before we start, each participant will shortly introduce herself/himself, and declare their tasks for the next work session. We recommend each participant to share your objective for each 25-minute session in the comments here for best results. We also allow people who couldn't make it and stayed at home to post their next task in the comment.

A volunteer will start a 25-minute timer, followed by 5-minute break timer (we recommend using this online timer: https://www.marinaratimer.com/
Remember to share the specific link to your timer in the group comments just before the first session, so everyone knows how much time is left, including the people who work at home.

At the end of a session (25 minutes), each participant will share with the group if their task was completed, and their next session task (also in comments), and we'll start again once the 5 minutes break ends.

What's next?

Join us at the next Work Jam, they are free for now. Also, if you enjoyed the productivity boost from working together and meeting new people consider joining a coworking space! Find it at our favourite and the world’s biggest coworking directory: https://www.coworker.com/

events.name: Design Community Brussels @ Movify!
events.description:
Hi everyone!

This meetup is dedicated to all people who create digital products and services.

Each month our speakers, industry experts, are sharing their knowledge and experience. Explore the world of design with us, get inspired and meet interesting people.

This month we have the following guests speakers:

1) DAMIEN VOSSEN

"Voice Experience - Year Zero"

After a few decades, we are finally at the point where voice technology is reliable enough to produce enjoyable experiences. More than ever, we need to think about how users will interact with those interfaces that can be amazingly powerful and frustrating at the same time. Damien will share with you what are the main usage today, how does it work from a technical point of view, explain you what are the specifications of voice experiences and what are the main challenges we still need to solve.

- Passionate about story telling and digital products, Damien has worked for the last 5 years as a product manager and UX strategist for startups, major media companies and banks. He likes to ease and accelerate digital innovative projects in a human-centric way: technology must adapt to humans, not the other way around. He worked on mobile apps, chatbots and voice applications, but what he likes the most is to learn new stuff and share my knowledge about UX.

2) JORN CRAEGHS

"Success of Silicon Valley Apps? Using Behavioural Psychology"

Why are we so addicted to our phones? How come Silicon Valley has got us hooked on apps? And what is their formula for success?
In his talk, Jorn will share the leading theories that Silicon Valley teams use to attract users and design behaviour.

- Jorn Craeghs is a Behavioural Designer. He uses his knowledge of behavioral psychology to understand human choices. And he comes up with interventions for behaviour change.
He has mastered the trade at SUE Amsterdam where he started out as a Behavioural Strategist and ended up as the Insights Lead. After that he designed and directed the Behavioural Design Academy. In 2017 Jorn became an entrepreneur, working under the name Sade Studio. He now turns his knowledge of behavioural psychology into ideas that have a positive impact on our lives.

-

Schedule:

18:00 - Opening doors, snacks & drinks.
18:30 - 2 talks of (+/-) 30 min
19:30 - Networking, snacks & drinks.

NOTE: We are starting talks at 18:30, with the doors opening at 18:00, so please arrive on time to ensure we run to schedule.

-

We look forward to seeing you!
Caroline, Mayti, & Karol.

-

PS. Would you like to hear a specific talk? Are you interested in some topics? Would you like to share a speech with others, or you know someone who could - let us know! We will be happy to provide what interests you the most.

events.name: Dev Community Brussels @ Movify!
events.description:
Hi everyone!

This month we will talk about "The Sounds of Android"

Speaker: Yannick Lemin

Summary :
Audio on Android is a topic that is rarely covered, which is why I wanted to shed some lights in my experience with the audio management APIs on the platform.

So in this talk, we'll touch on how sounds actually work programmatically, and we'll talk about how to play a sound on Android in the most simple way. We will also cover the principle of sound focus, what it is, how and when to use it. We'll see what we can do with MIDI as well. And finally, we'll go deeper in the rabbit hole and get introduced to the lower levels of sounds processing with the help of OpenSL ES and the SuperPowered library.

Let's bring the noise.

Entry level : Beginner

// Bonus // Yannick will also share his experience with drones and on the integration of the SDK parrot in a mobile app + Demo of a proof of concept

Schedule:

18:00 - Opening doors, snacks & drinks.
18:30 - Let's talk Drones
19:00 - The Sounds of Android
19:45 - Networking, snacks & drinks.

NOTE: We are starting the talks at 18:30, with the doors opening at 18:00, so please arrive on time to ensure we run on schedule.

We look forward to seeing you!
Yannick, Mayti & Cédric

events.name: Chastre – Couture-Saint-Germain (24km) – La Hulpe (33km) – Flagey (51km)
events.description:
Just a small note before the description: as you may know, as members of the BHG, we are planning to do the 100km Oxfam Trailwalker in August. Our first group, The Smoothies, is raising funds (1500€) for Oxfam on that occasion. If you feel you want to support our challenge, we’ll be very grateful for any contribution. Our webpage is here: www.oxfamtrailwalker.be/en/editions/oxfam-trailwalker-2018/the-smoothies

Btw, for a tax receipt, see here: www.oxfamtrailwalker.be/en/the-challenge/revenue-of-oxfam-trailwalker/tax-receipt-for-belgium
-------------------------------------------------------

As promised, we’re increasing our distances during the coming weeks. We go for +50km this weekend. Always with some possibilities to leave or join the hike.

Here the distances and the estimated timing, including breaks. You decide, whenever you want, where you prefer to stop:

- Chastre – Couture-Saint-Germain: 24km (TEC bus 36 to Braine-l’Alleud + train to Brussels) / estimated arrival at 16:30
- Chastre – La Hulpe: 33km (TEC bus 366 to Brussels) / estimated arrival at 19:00
- Chastre – Flagey: 51km / estimated arrival at 23:00

●● Description:
We meet at 09:10 in front of the Starbucks in Brussels Central.
The train (ICT6960 direction Wavre) to Ottignies leaves from platform 3 at 09:22. It arrives at 09:58 in Ottignies, where we change for the train (L6260 direction Namur) to Chastre, leaving from platform 4 at 10:05. We reach our destination at 10:16 and start our hike.

We’ll go directly west towards Villers-la-Ville and pass in front of its well-known abbey. We’ll then turn north towards Couture-Saint-Germain, Ohain and then La Hulpe.

In Couture-Saint-Germain, after 24km, you’ll be able to go back to Brussels by public transport. There is a stop for the TEC bus 36 (Wavre – Braine-l’Alleud) to go to Braine-l’Alleud and from there the train to Brussels.
The bus schedule is here:
www.infotec.be/fr-be/medeplacer/horaires/ligne.aspx?ligne=B36&titre=Braine-l'Alleud - Wavre

Further on the way, after 33km, we’ll reach the La Hulpe castle. Arriving from a side entrance, we won’t pass trough the main Domain’s entrance. However, there you’ll easily find the stop “Etangs Solvay”, where you can catch the TEC bus 366 (Court-St-Etienne – Ixelles) to return directly to Brussels. Last services at 18:52 and 19:52 on Saturday.
Of course, you may join us there also, if you prefer to do only the last 18km through the forest.
www.infotec.be/fr-be/medeplacer/horaires/ligne.aspx?ligne=B366&titre=366%20Court-St-Etienne%20-%20Rixensart%20-%20Ixelles/Elsene

In front of the castle, we’ll have a good break, relaxing before our last shot. For that part, we’ll follow an itinerary running entirely trough the Sonian forest, up to the Bois de la Cambre. We’ll arrive late in Flagey, around 23:00. A tiring Saturday maybe. But, walking and discussing... that’s the kind of life we enjoy.

Come and join!

Note: if you plan to join us in La Hulpe, to do only the last leg, let me know it by sending me a message or leaving one on the comments section. Thanks.
(...and thank you Karin for the pic)

●● Details:
Distance: ~ 51km
Elevation gain: ~ 500m
Net walking time: ~ 11h00
Level: intermediate
Weather forecast: 12°-15°C / sunny / no rain

In the unlikely case of too bad weather, we may cancel a hike, even few hours before the event. If this must happen, we will of course update the Meetup website and send out an email to those registered. So, it is important to have access to either the Meetup.com website and/or your emails.

●● What to bring:
- raincoat / softshell
- water + lunch for the break
- Compeeds for blisters

●● Basic rules:
Please RSVP only if you really intend to come. And if your plans change, update your RSVP asap, even hours before the walk. This is basic courtesy towards others. Repeated late cancellations are not well considered (at all). No-shows even worse.

Do not show up for a hike unless you are on the roster (i.e. Yes RSVP, but not Wait Listed).

events.description:
Note - as we move into Fall/Winter if it is raining at or close to start time and there is rain forecast for the entire morning consider the ride cancelled. I won't always cancel the event but common sense prevails. Also big wind storms can also cause cancellation as trail access can be closed.

Ride length is generally about 35 kms at a pace of 18 kph with stops as needed so people catch up. We are probably best described as intermediate to advanced in terms of fitness and speed. We do have occasional beginner rides too.
Please bring:

A mountain bike ! This is important. Please no hybrids or road bikes - they wont make it where we ride.

A helmet - mandatory. No helmet = no ride with us.

Bring some water and a snack,

A spare tube. Don't worry if you don't know how to fix a flat, one of us can help with that.

DON'T BRING:

A bike that is going to fall apart or leave you walking. Brakes need to brake, wheels need to be properly inflated. Shifters need to shift !

A bad attitude !

Meet at:

Cool island / Ave Louise
Avenue Louise 589, 1000 Bruxelles

goo.gl/maps/qKG78wnW2dk

As an FYI we're the http://www.bigm.be/ Big M mountain bike club. We invite you to come out and join us. If you decide that this is a club you'd like to join the yearly dues are 15 euros and that entitles you to access to our members only forum and calendar etc.

events.name: Accelerated Learning: How Agile Can Help You?
events.description:
Hello everyone,

We are pleased to invite you to our meetup about Accelerated Learning: How Agile Can Help You?
The evening will be animated by Artur Margonari, Agile Coach, Trainer and Facilitator at Wemanity Belgium

Have you ever thought about applying your Agile knowledge to learn something you want? Want to learn how to play an instrument? Want to learn a new language? Or how to juggle balls? Whatever is the new skill, believe me: Agile can help you with it.

In our life, we often face the need of learning something new. It can be to use in our jobs, to impress the person we love, to simply have fun or as a new hobby. Whatever is the reason, we know it can be challenging to acquire a new skill and it cannot be (yet) downloaded straight into our brain, like in some nice movies. We still need to read books, follow classes, research, practice and be patient. And the learning curve might be very slow.

I’ll share with the audience a technique to learn anything new very fast!
The reason why this method caught my attention: it’s incredibly similar to Agile values, principles, and practices! Thus, if you know what Agile is about, you are halfway to use it in your favor to learn anything you want, fast.

Agenda
18h - Welcome + networking
18h30 - Presentation starts
19h45 - End of presentation, let's talk over some pizzas and beers :)

If you answer YES please make sure you come, or update your RSVP accordingly when you cannot make it!

See you there!

The Wemanity Team (http://wemanity.com)

events.name: Reading The Passions and the Interests
events.description:
Within the Capital Series and for those who are up for a slightly bigger commitment, I propose we read and then discuss the following book:

Albert O. Hirschman (1977) The Passions and the Interests: Political Arguments for Capitalism Before Its Triumph (135 pages, foreword and notes not included)

How the pursuit of material interests (so long seen as a vice) came to be seen as the way to contain the unruly and destructive passions of men. The repression of the passions in favour of the "harmless", if one-dimensional, interests in commercial life. I believe it invites further discussion about the intellectual underpinnings for capitalism alive in 2018 and our position in society - as consumers first and foremost? Also: what is (then and now presented as) the moral basis for capitalism?

Mark Blyth on The Passions and the Interests (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wrsh_bqoRBY&t=132s): [paraphrased] "It gives you the evolution of capitalism in under 200 pages. It puts concisely what took Foucault several books written in tortured language; in order to have liberal capitalism, first liberal economic subjects need to be created. The creation of those subjects is a political project." You're welcome to rsvp in order to keep in the loop of the event. The date will be set later this Spring, preferably together. If you join the event, it is understood that you make an effort of acquainting yourself with the text in whatever capacity. I suggest reading the book, available here at 14,30 euro: https://www.bookdepository.com/The-Passions-and-the-Interests-Albert-O-Hirschman-Jeremy-Adelman-Amartya-Sen/9780691160252?ref=grid-view&qid=1519645229288&sr=1-1.

Blurbs:

In this volume, Albert Hirschman reconstructs the intellectual climate of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries to illuminate the intricate ideological transformation that occurred, wherein the pursuit of material interests --so long condemned as the deadly sin of avarice --was assigned the role of containing the unruly and destructive passions of man. Hirschman here offers a new interpretation for the rise of capitalism, one that emphasizes the continuities between old and new, in contrast to the assumption of a sharp break that is a common feature of both Marxian and Weberian thinking. (...) To portray this lengthy ideological change as an endogenous process, Hirschman draws on the writings of a large number of thinkers, including Montesquieu, Sir James Steuart, and Adam Smith.

- Goodreads

This is a history of the ideas laying the intellectual groundwork for capitalism. Hirschman describes how thinkers in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries embraced the sin of avarice as an important counterweight to humankind's destructive passions. Capitalism was promoted by thinkers including Montesquieu, Sir James Steuart, and Adam Smith as repressing the passions for "harmless" commercial activities. Hirschman noted that words including "vice" and "passion" gave way to "such bland terms" as "advantage" and "interest."

Hirschman described The Passions and the Interests as the book he most enjoyed writing. According to Hirschman biographer Jeremy Adelman, the book reflected Hirschman's political moderation, a challenge to reductive accounts of human nature by economists as a "utility-maximizing machine" as well as Marxian or communitarian "nostalgia for a world that was lost to consumer avarice."
- Adelman, Jeremy (April 7, 2013). Worldly Philosopher: The Odyssey of Albert O. Hirschman

events.name: 24km  around Geraardsbergen with a glider airport and the bird sanctuary
Celebrate Eid- medieval castles,beautiful beaches & fresh sea food of Portugal
events.description:
asalam o alaikum folks

Lets celebrate Eid in some sunny coastal cities of portugal. This trip will cover central and south of porugal. As usual, out trip is a mix of adventure and city break. The flexible itinerary is as follows

day 1 (3rd july) - land in lisbon. Check in , have a shower. Smell the air, Walk around the city and get to know each other. We will go to different view points(Miradouro ) in the city , which are higher than sea level, to get stunning views. Visit the famous tower in lisbon to get panoramic views. And then soak ourselves into beautiful sunset at the beach (15 mins walk away from lisbon). Have delicious dinner after at one of the restaurant at the beach

day 2 - after breakfast, we will head off to explore lisbon - visit the near by districts of lisbon. Visit alfama (the famous castle made by north african muslims). Explore lisbon in famous historical portugese trams.

day 3 - We will spend one day in sintra and spend the night back in lisbon. Sintra is a resort town in the foothills of Portugal’s Sintra Mountains, A longtime royal sanctuary, its forested terrain is studded with pastel-colored villas and palaces. With its rippling mountains, dewy forests thick with ferns and lichen, exotic gardens and glittering palaces, Sintra is like a page torn from a fairy tale. Its Unesco World Heritage site. It also holds a moorish Castle(Castelo dos Mouros) and monseratte palace. we will cover some of these sites http://www.sintra-portugal.com/guides/sintra-things-to-see.html

day 4 - head to Lagos. Take train from lisbon to Lagos(algarve region).
checking, walk around the city , explore the historic sites. Take a boat trip to ponta de piedade, which will take us through the caves on atlantic ( ned to be booked ). and as usual, after soaking ourselves in the beautiful sunset , we will have dinner and get ready for the next day

day 5 - we will go out hiking for a day in the untrodden area of west coast of portugal, also called end of the world.. It will be up and down and good 4-5 hours of walking/ scrambling along the coast. We will be rewarded with stunning views. Bring packed lunch with you. ( need to be booked in advance)

day 6 - free day - a day for you to choose any activity you would like. Or just stay in a cafe and sip coffee.

day 7 - day trip to Sives, which is an acient moorish town and was capital of algarve region when muslims were ruling the region. It was also an important trade route between north africa and europe.

day 8 - Explore the beautiful town of Lagos with its cobbled streets and old churches. There will be options to choose from a few activities such as treetop climbing, surfing. - we will return to lisbon in the evening

day 9 - explore what was left in lisbon including the beautiful mosque and fly back home with some great memories

Accomodation: there is plenty of choice of rooms on airbnb and booking,com .. You book what you like. Alternatively, we can all book a bigger house ( with swimming pool etc). That would be cheaper and better. We will decide together

Flights:
You are free to join and leave the trip as you want . But its better to stay together.
The recommended flights (which i have booked are)
Ryanair 2925 ; bRU - LIS - departing 9.25 AM - landing 11.20 AM
Ryanair 2932; LIS - BRU - deparing 17.30 - landing 9:15 PM

The price of those flights are about 120 Euros return. So hurry up and book now

Clothing : Bring good walking shoes (trainers) and a warm layer.
Food: There are plenty of good veggie options available for non-meat eaters. Portugal is famous for its fresh fish. And there is ample halal food available too.

I look forward to you joining us
Any questions, send me a message

Ciao
Shahzad

events.name: #AI Demystified meetup at ULB
events.description:
Dear Friends,

On June 27th the Data Science Community will hold its 4th annual conference at the ULB. You can expect a day packed with innovative ideas, lots of networking opportunities and FUN. We will have 40 speakers, 6 master classes and 6 hands-on workshops, all in the efforts of demystifying Artificial Intelligence.

The Keynote speaker: There is a budget for getting the best A.I. expert able at bringing the true face of A.I. to light to us to speak at this year’s Summit. So if you have someone in mind that impressed you recently, please send me his/her details.

The location: In the previous 3 editions of the Summit, we constantly had trouble fitting all our eager participants into the available space. No more. This year, we reserved a much much bigger location for you all - 2,5 time larger to be exact - with one plenary seating room of 800 seats and 6 big training rooms on 2 floors at the ULB Solbosch Campus Auditorium K.

Partner Village and Job Fair: There will be 2 vast areas for networking. One for the partners to show off their innovative ideas; the other for all to hire their best candidates.

Invite your team: Make from #disummit your annual team event and have a productive day with your team at the University of Brussels.

Recruit the best: You can promote your outstanding jobs, participate to the Job Fair and sponsor some tickets for students.
Network and Nerd-Out: Opportunities to network and have fun will be plenty. We will use the conversation starter app again to facilitate your connexion with the most pertinent people. After the Summit, we have a beer garden set up for you to nerd-out after work with craft beer and a barbecue. Yes.

Spread the word: As we have more capacity this year, we are implementing a special incentive program to reward your help in promoting the Summit. You are invited to bring your community at discounted rates and to earn free tickets.

More information on disummit.com

I’m looking forward to meeting you again! Don’t hesitate to contact me, should you have any questions.

events.name: Café Samedi
events.description:
Lets meet for a nice cup of coffee, a tea or hot chocolate. With or without something sweet on the side. It’s time for some serious and not so serious chatting. For newcomers in town, this is an excellent opportunity to meet some people in a relaxed environment. And for those who visited Expat Club events before an excellent way to again experience our international community of open-minded people. We meet in Natural Caffè Mont des Arts, right in the heart of Brussels, not far from Central Station, Bozar and Grand Place.

You are welcome to join us from 10h30 until 12h30. You can drop in any time, although we prefer you come earlier rather than later. We will be standing around the long table and you’ll surely recognise the Expat Club logo. Feel free to bring your friends, colleagues or family!

Don't forget to pick up your free copy of the Expats in Brussels guide, the special "Expat Club" edition. It's the reference work for expats in this town! You can also download a pdf version (http://expatsinbrussels.be/ExpatsInBrussels-2016.pdf) of the guide here, but of course the hard copy is much nicer.

RULES OF THE COFFEE MORNING
• Registration with email address is required if it is your first time with Expat Club.
• Wearing a name tag helps a lot for people to get to know each other. Thanks for writing your name on the special labels.
• Due to past complaints, please be aware that it is not allowed to purposefully join us for the coffee morning with the intend to make sales pitches. We do not want any soliciting for religious, spiritual, financial, self-development, multi-level-marketing, health and other such programs or events.
• Our gatherings are meant to meet other people and discover new things while in Brussels.You are not the only one at the table, please don't try to dominate discussions and be respectful of other people's opinions.
events.how_to_find_us: We're at the big table, you can't miss us :-)  Just get yourself a coffee and write your name on a label. That's it! You're ready now to join the table.

events.name: ▼- Marche Active / Zen & Workshop Végétarian -▼

venue.name: au parking de l'Hippodrome de Boisfort

events.description:
▼- Marche Active / Zen & Workshop Végétarian -▼

- Forêt de Soignes -

" Un déjeuner sain lors d'une activité physique; le goût et l’odorat..

Développez, découvrez cette faculté, ce sens, et vous retrouverez la joie dans les doux parfums, vous aiderez ainsi le haut de votre corps à se ré-harmoniser, à se recentrer dans une sensation de bien-être."

- ✧ Le végétarisme ✧-...

Le végétarisme est une pratique alimentaire qui remonte à la Grèce Antique. De nombreux philosophes grecs étaient végétariens, dont Pythagore, que l’on considère comme le père du végétarisme. Dans un premier temps, on nommait "pythagoriciens" les personnes qui excluaient la viande de leur régime alimentaire. Plus tard, le végétarisme a conquis de nombreux autres penseurs et scientifiques célèbres comme Albert Einstein, Léonard de Vinci et Mahatma Gandhi.

Il existe différentes catégories de végétarisme, de végétalisme et de véganisme , mais nous allons nous concentrer sur la définition globale de ce terme.

Le végétarisme fait référence à un type d’alimentation qui exclut la viande (viande rouge et viande blanche), les poissons et les fruits de mer.

-✧ Acti'march ou Marche Active ✧-

Ce n’est pas une «promenade»...C'est une « discipline douce », qui développe l'endurance. C’est un entraînement (régulier) qui va permettre d’améliorer la condition physique en douceur, sans fatigue excessive. La marche active est une marche dynamique pratiquée de façon continue sur terrain plat. Elle a été élaborée par la fédération de gymnastique volontaire en collaboration avec des scientifiques et des médecins.

- ✧ Le Bain de Forêt ✧-

Un cocktail de bienfaits tout en profitant de la nature en se «déconnectant». Le Shinrin-Yoku, littéralement « bain de forêt », est né au Japon dans les années 80, les avantages pour la santé de cette activité consistant à passer du temps en forêt, sont reconnus dans d’autres cultures. Cependant, seul le Japon a fait de cette pratique une pierre angulaire de sa politique de médecine préventive. Une pratique qui repose sur une littérature scientifique de plus en plus abondante. C’est l’Agence des forêts japonaise qui a été la première a introduire le terme Shinrin-Yoku au début des années 80.

L’idée était d’inciter les Japonais à se promener en forêt et à éveiller les sens du corps aux nombreuses interactions que le milieu forestier offre.

Cette pratique est reconnue comme une véritable hygiène de vie et l’influence des environnements forestiers sur nos sens.

▼- Les Objectifs :

Les objectifs de la Marche Active & Zen / Workshop Végétarian en forêt est de familiariser les participants à la cuisine végétarienne et végétalienne lors d'une marche active et douce, de découvrir leurs bénéfices sur la santé physique, mentale, le bien-être et ses multiples effets et bienfaits.

- ✧ Les bienfaits et les effets de la nutrition végétarienne et végétalienne -

" Une seule journée passée sans manger de viande économise 5000 litres d’eau !

La consommation d’eau des ménages n'est rien par rapport à ce que coûte l’agriculture et particulièrement les productions animales."

- Bienfaits sur notre santé -

- Les repas végétariens apportent une plus grande variété d’éléments nutritifs. Ils sont plus riches en fibres, en antioxydants, en vitamines et en minéraux. Ils sont une excellente source de protéines et de glucides complexes, donc d’énergie. Les lipides (gras) renferment moins de gras saturés et de cholestérol.

- Pour vivre plus longtemps et en meilleure santé : une alimentation de plus en plus végétarienne réduit les risques de certains types de cancer, dont le cancer colorectal , de maladies inflammatoires, d’hypertension, de maladies cardio-vasculaires, d’obésité, de diabète, de maladies rénales, d’empoisonnement alimentaire, d’ostéoporose, de démence,..

- Certitude documentée : les protéines végétales variées peuvent répondre adéquatement à nos besoins nutritionnels en protéines.

( *Voir la suite des bienfaits et effets )

- ✧ Les bienfaits et les effets de la marche -

Accessible à tous, la marche est une activité d’intensité moyenne qui permet d’entretenir son système cardio-vasculaire et de se tonifier des pieds à la tête.

La marche sollicite le travail de tous les muscles du corps en douceur. Pratiquée régulièrement, elle permet de purifier son organisme en stimulant le transit intestinal et d’évacuer le stress en sécrétant des endorphines, les fameuses hormones du bonheur, elle lutte efficacement contre les tensions du quotidien.

La marche pousse l'organisme à brûler des calories et à convertir les glucides, les graisses et les protéines en énergie plutôt qu'en réserves adipeuses, les muscles sont renforcés, la silhouette est affinée.

Elle prévient le risque de maladies cardiovasculaires et du diabète, améliore la fonction cardiaque, le cœur bat moins vite au repos et les capacités respiratoires sont améliorées.

Elle facilite la résistance à l’effort, les risques de douleurs articulaires et les blessures sont réduites contrairement à d’autres activités. Enfin, La marche a des nombreux bénéfices sur la santé physique, mentale et le bien-être. (*voir)

- ✧Les bienfaits et les effets du bain de forêt -

Les études démontrent que le bain de forêt joue un rôle bénéfique sur la tension, la dépression, l’anxiété, la fatigue, la confusion; le cortisol salivaire diminue et donc le taux de glucose dans le sang baisse chez les diabétiques. Il agit sur l’humeur, donc on constate un meilleur sentiment de vivacité, une baisse de l’hostilité et de l’état dépressif, et bien d'autres...L’influence des environnements forestiers sur nos sens démontre que nos systèmes sensoriels sont influencés par les informations reçues de façon visuelle, auditive, olfactive et même tactile.

▼- Programme -

✧ Lors de ce workshop, nous vous proposons de découvrir la cuisine végétarienne et végétalienne à travers un atelier consacré à l'ail des ours que nous trouvons en forêt au début du printemps ; de la découvrir et d'y goutter toutes les saveurs avec un grand Chef de cuisine du monde végétarienne, végétalienne.

* Echauffement.

* Marche Active de 1 heure.

* Workshop Végétarian et dégustation.

* Marche douce et bain de forêt de 1 heure 30, le retour sera suivi d'un temps de questions- réponses.

* Etirements.

- Matériel :

Le cours se donnera en plein air, donc chaque participant devra prévoir les éléments suivants :

• Tapis de yoga ou couverture.

• Tenue confortable et adaptée au temps.(souple de préférence.)

• Des bonnes chaussures de marche.

• Sac à dos le plus léger possible.

• Prévoir de l'eau.

▼ Réservations & Renseignements -

- Bienfaits sur les sociétés :

- Parce que manger de plus en plus végétarien aide à prévenir différentes maladies, la consommation de végétaux réduira le gouffre abyssal des coûts de santé. La prévention a bien meilleur coût.

- Plus de 70 % des cultures céréalières produites dans les pays en voie de développement ou sous-développés sont exportées ou données aux animaux d’élevage.

- Pour économiser : les céréales et les légumineuses coûtent moins cher à la production, à l’achat et à la conservation. Ceci permettra d’ acheter davantage de légumes.

- Pour une meilleure répartition des denrées dans le monde et pour combattre la faim.

- Bienfaits sur l’environnement :

- Pour sauvegarder les réserves d’eau douce de la planète.

- Pour réduire la destruction des forêts et sauvegarder la biodiversité.

- Pour diminuer les gaz à effets de serre.

- Le méthane est responsable pour la moitié du réchauffement climatique à cause humaine. Le principal émetteur de méthane est l’agriculture.

- Pour diminuer la pollution du sol, de l’air et de l’eau produite par les fermes d’élevage industriel.

- Bienfaits sur les animaux :

- Pour des questions d’éthique et de sauvegarde des animaux terrestres et aquatiques.

- Compassion et éthique :

- Manger est un geste significatif qui passe par notre éducation et comporte des liens et des répercussions bien au-delà de notre faim à assouvir et de nos habitudes alimentaires acquises.

« Rien ne pourra être plus bénéfique à la santé humaine ni accroître les chances de survie de la vie sur la Terre, qu'une évolution vers un régime végétarien. » – Albert Einstein acquises.

« L’enfant qui sait se pencher sur l’animal souffrant saura un jour tendre la main à son frère. » – Albert Schweitzer

(*)Les bienfaits de la marche active :

• Elle permet de stimuler le métabolisme.

• Améliore la souplesse musculaire.

• Renforce et tonifie les muscles de la face postérieure : les mollets, les fessiers, le haut du dos et les épaules, sans solliciter trop violemment les articulations, donc en limitant les risques de blessures.

• Prévient les maladies cardio-vasculaires.

• Renforce la tonicité des muscles.

• D'améliorer les capactés de concentration en irriguant favorablement le cerveau .

• Evacue le stress.

• Renforce le système immunitaire.

• Désintoxique le corps.

• Améliore le sommeil.

• Purifie le teint...

events.name: Compassionate Mind Workshop
events.description:
CompassionateMind introductory workshop aims at helping you understand, recognise and utilise the principles of compassion to develop and maintain healthy mental wellbeing.

“You've been criticising yourself for years and it hasn't worked. Try approving of yourself and see what happens."

Compassion towards oneself can have a significant impact on one's wellbeing by influencing our ability to form and maintain healthy relationships with others.

CompassionateMind is theory created by Paul Gilbert which underpins on the evolution of the mammalian and specifically the human brain. We strive to survive in a forever changing and threatening environment. Compassion towards itself has been scientifically proven to increase a sense of happiness and wellbeing.

CompassionateMind will help you feel more Self accepting, balanced and mindful.
"Compassion is what separates us from the reptiles and birds"

Who will deliver the workshop:
Saquib Ahmad, consultant psychotherapist offers psychotherapy privately to those suffering from mental health problems in Belgium and UK. Currently involved in the recovery of the survivals of the Grenfell Tower fire of June 2017 in London. Specialist in working with depression, anxiety and trauma 1:1 and groups. Offers consultations to professionals and organisations internationally.

Price: 25 Euro
In order to confirm your booking you will have to make a bank transfer to the following account by 25 June 2018:
Saquib Naveed Ahmad - BE[masked].

events.name: Trees in the City: Coaching Yourself and Others with Nature
events.description:
Workshop: Trees in the City
Coaching Yourself and Others with Nature
By Greet Selderslaghs

Brussels: 27 June 2018
http://www.imaginationclub.org/brussels/trees_in_the_city.php

Nature offers us powerful images which can easily be related to our own growth and to helping others to grow. From the smallest flower on the pavement to the largest tree, all of creation whispers to us and brings hidden messages for us to discover.

Nature offers us … space. Space to stand still, space for reflection. It becomes easier to find your own rhythm, to get in touch with what is inside you and wants to be expressed. In this workshop, we will discover different ways of introducing nature in coaching sessions or for your own growth.

Depending on the weather, part of the workshop will be held outside, in the lovely garden of Timesmore. Tree hugging optional.

About Greet Selderslaghs
Greet Selderslaghs Is passionate about reconnecting people to their true nature. Among her earliest childhood memories are the smell of fertile soil after the rain; her grandfather leaning on his spade, contemplating the growing crops; and life in general. Greet first misinterpreted her desire to help people –not crops- to grow, and studied interior design, wanting to create a space for people to feel good. She had an interesting journey, as a civil servant, a management assistant, a manager, a teacher, a ceremony master. That included a severe burn-out, long before the term became well known (yes, she likes to pioneer).

Greet now enjoys being self-employed; enjoying life as a coach and workshop facilitator; and teaching Biodanza. Find out more at www.artofgoodliving.eu, and www.itworkstomove.eu.

Practical Information
When?
Wednesday, 27 June 2018 from 18h45-21h00

Where?
Timesmore
Boulevard St Michel 47, 1040 Brussels
Public transport: Metro: Montgomery; Tram: Boileau

How much?
A contribution of €12 to cover expenses including materials, drinks, snacks, etc.

Event web page http://www.imaginationclub.org/brussels/trees_in_the_city.php

Confirm Your Participation
If you wish to attend this workshop, and have not already done so, please confirm your place by sending an e-mail to [masked] or following the link above. You are welcome to invite guests. But do let us know how many guests you'll bring along. If you change your mind, please let us know right away. If you do not wish to have your name appear on the attendee list in the web, please let us know in your reply. Registration to workshops may be limited.

events.description:
Dear,

We would like to invite you to discover the art and science of Pranic Healing by becoming a pranic healer.

With this no-touching energy healing technique you will be able to apply energy healing on yourself, other people, animals, situations, projects, and much more. No previous knowledge about energy nor healing techniques are required. You just need to have an open mind!

Lift the things: free weights strength training
events.description:
This is the last meetup until August because I will be in Canada in July.

Hello all,

I have been doing free weights strength training since 2015 and I am currently looking for (a) gym budd{y|ies} to make it a more pleasant experience.

This is the same routine I started with and I have been very happy with the results, it is well suited for beginners and intermediate lifters alike (I would be happy to show you the ways if needed.)

• What we'll do
5x5 squats ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Squat_(exercise) )
5x5 bench presses ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bench_press )
1x5 dead lifts ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deadlift )
3x 90 seconds plank ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plank_(exercise) )

Some advantages of free weights over machines:
- Strengthen core and stabilizer muscles (useful in real life)
- Train all muscle groups instead of targeting specific "good looking" ones (form follows function)
- Safer (the whole body is gradually prepared to handle heavier weights, and there are no uniform movements that could cause repetitive strain)
- Exciting!

• What to bring
Water bottle
Flat-bottom shoes (eg: converse, vans)
Notebook or notetaking app to track progress

events.name: Lets collect some interesting/old/pretty things at the flea market
events.description:
Hallo everyone!

I have changed the time of meet up to 3 march, because I am not in brussels in the weeks before that and it should finally get a little warmer. I hope we can meet and browse through the market and maybe even play a game in the way I imagine it.

We will have a budget about 5-8 euros and we will look for things that interest us within this budget. In the end we meet and show what we found and we decide who the collecting winner is. Don't worry if you won't find anything, it will be fun anyway. The meet up can happen only if there is no heavy rain.

Last meetup was very inspiring to me thanks to Clara who joined me on a sunny day to browse through the flea market. We talked a bit about the things we like and meanwhile she admires art deco, me I am more into little useful things, which make me happy when I look at them. Each time when I go to the flea market I have a thing in my mind, something I need at home and this time it was a little dose to store pepper. And I found a perfect one (see the picture in gallery). I am happy to announce that this little thing is a winner of this week, since there were no other buys. :D

While we were walking, Clara has pointed out many interesting things like for example old wooden stands for hats, meanwhile me I was admiring a "silent-waiter" (thanks Clara for this word) - double level serving plate from Italy. We couldn't afford to buy all those things, but I regret that we didn't take pictures. And that's another challenge for the next meet up, except usual challenge stated above we are also going to make pictures of real antique things which we think could be interesting for collectors and post them here and possibly announce winner as well.

See you!

Lucia

events.name: Anatomy of a conflict and its behavioral components

venue.name: Brussels
venue.address_1: The location of the meeting will depend on the number of participants and will be announced

events.description:
This Meetup is a review with some novelty for some of you and an initial contact with the field of conflict management for those who are unfamiliar with it. It is intended for those who meet some of the following criteria:

· You experience conflict in your professional life on a regular basis

· You experience conflicts in your personal life

· You are under stress and would like to know how to cope with it

· You would like to improve the way you related to people

· You try to avoid conflict as much as you can

· You fear situations that are potentially conflictual

· You apprehend any context that is emotionally charged

Almost no one enjoys conflict. Everyone tries to avoid it. In fact, we work hard to master conflict avoidance skills. We teach our kids in school not to get into fights, avoid disagreements, walk away, give in or give up. We socialize young girls and adult women to value the relationship above their own personal interests or needs.

As a result we are an intimacy starved culture. We raise children who do not know how to manage their anger, or productively deal with conflict. Where do our children learn how to fight, when to fight and what is worth fighting for?

--- Description ---
In this meetup we'll focus on Azure and the cognitive services which tend to be undervalued and not well known. Alexander Klein will tell you everything that you need to know about them and will show you how to use them!

--- Agenda ---
• 18:00 - 18:30 - Free food & drinks, sponsored by Ordina
• 18:30 - 20:30 - Azure Cognitive Services - Introduction, possibilities and application example
• 20:30 - ??:?? - Drinks, discussions and fun

--- Session 1: Azure Cognitive Services - Introduction, possibilities and application example ---
Microsoft Cognitive Services (formerly Project Oxford) are a set of APIs, SDKs, and services that developers can use to make their applications smarter, more engaging, and more discoverable. Cognitive Services extend Microsoft's AI platform.

This is a large playground for young and old. Here you can try out to your heart's content what will be in use tomorrow. With the various building blocks such as Bot Framework, Emotion, Face, Text Analytics or Recommendations, to name but a few, impressive applications can be assembled in a short time.

Speaker: Alexander Klein is a Senior Business Intelligence Consultant with more than 15 years of experience. His focus is on business intelligence and data warehouse projects with Microsoft technologies such as SQL Server, Power BI, Azure ML or Cognitive Services. Since 2008 he has been working as a freelance consultant in large and medium-sized projects in all industries in Europe. He has been visiting SQL Saturdays throughout Europe since 2013.

events.name: Afterwork Session: Cosmic Encounter
events.description:
Cosmic encounter is one of the modern classics of Board Game.

Each player will assume a race with a unique superpower. Each turn runs through several phases.

*start turn: you ensure you have at least one encounter card in your hand,
*Regroup: retrieve a ship from the warp
*Destiny: Pull a destiny card and see where you go
*Launch: launch your ships at a planet
*alliance: first the attacker, then the defender invite others to be their allies
*planning: you pick your encounter card
*reveal: you reveal your encounter card
*resolution: resolve who won the encounter.
If the attacker one, they can have a second round (if they still have encounter cards). If not, the next species has their go.

Deals will be made, negotiations will be sabotaged... and new colonies will be formed.
Who has as first race 5 foreign colonies wins the game :)

events.name: Coaching Circle
events.description:
• What we'll do
Creating communities that foster deep conversations:

Reinventing Brussels is on a mission to connect people and to initiate & support communities that create a welcoming & sustainable city with deep human values. This is why we value the emergence of communities that share these values and communities that are practicing deep conversations. To do so, we would like to foster the use of tools that get this kind of conversations and the one we found most useful is the case clinic used in coaching circles, a practice from Theory U by Otto Scharmer from the MIT.

Coaching circles:

Peer circles that use deep listening–based coaching practices are one of the most important mechanisms for holding the space for deep conversations and learning. A coaching circle usually consists of five to seven members and applies a version of the case clinic, a simple tool that doesn’t need any training. We have found that the power of these peer group circles is simply amazing. They hold the space for individual and shared renewal. As one practitioner put it in a recent coaching call with his colleagues: “You [the whole circle] are the cradle of my rebirth.” This may sound fairy-fairy or sentimental to some, but it is in fact an accurate description of a subtle experience that all of us—and many others in their circles—have experienced.

• What to bring

• Important to know

events.name: Philosophical Café
events.description:
The philosophical café is a format for 'doing philosophy' right off the bat without the need for preparation or a capacity to throw around names of great philosophers. During the café we try to reflect on ourselves and our beliefs and convictions through posing a philosophical question and with a moderator to guide the conversation.

We ask each other and ourselves questions and get insights from listening rather than working on our art of convincing. In doing practical philosophy, we draw on our experience both in coming up with themes and questions, and tangling with them. The atmosphere with something to drink and a shared question remains light-hearted as well.

The below gives you all the info you need to join the café. Please read.

THEMES INTO QUESTIONS:
The first 30 minutes of the café, so from 14h, we form small subgroups. Each subgroup will get together to talk about (a) theme(s) they feel could be right for the later conversation around a question. Come to get inspired or come with a theme that you can propose to your subgroup. Perhaps you have a theme that struck you from recent experience.

The subgroup decides on one or two themes and already turns them into questions or proposes a theme to the whole group to then come up with a final question form. Don't hesitate to work on formulating a seemingly more narrow theme and question. When thinking of work for instance, one might hear oneself/another say that they're facing a tricky moment in their life and need to achieve or feel they're not achieving.

It's hard to see where to go when "life" or even "work" are the theme of the philosophical café. In talking with the subgroup together, you might find in this case the theme to be "achieving" and consequently the question could be 'when is something an achievement?'. We can use the real-world experience of the whole group to engage in conversation and it can open up different angles (work, private life or even what we are doing with the philosophical café right now).

More on formulating questions:

A question should be 7 words max.

A workable (for the time that we have) question doesn't contain more than one or potentially two concepts (which we will need to investigate).

Some examples of questions (in no particular order):

- What is freedom?

- What does it mean to be negative?

- When is something humiliating?

- When is naivety a virtue?

- What is the Internet?

- When is something an obsession?

VOTING:
Everybody gets to vote on each proposed question. You can choose to vote for each option you like, only the one you like best or anything in between. Any question with the most votes is selected. In case of ties for most votes, we have a second, final round of voting.

LANGUAGE:
The philosophical café will be in English. There is no need to be a native speaker - and most participants are not. A good working knowledge of English works. I moderate so we speak one at a time and insuring we understand each other's position.

LOCATION:
We are meeting at Les Meubles du Coeur. Drinks can only be paid in cash. Please be there on time so we can get settled in and get started quickly. I will be there a bit before 14h.

Hope to see you all, including new faces, soon!

events.name: Predictably intelligent - the (Behavioural) Economics of Artificial Intelligence
events.description:
AI + BE = ??

Artificial Intelligence (AI) - what are the consequences for business and private life and what has it do with Behavioral Economics (BE?).

The Meetup wants to discuss the guiding hypothesis of a recently published book on Artificial Intelligence. The authors Agrawal et al. argue that the main effect of AI is a drastic drop in the cost of predictions.

If this is correct, we need to look into this. Why? Because it is one of the core ideas of BE that people systematically err when making predictions. If predictions are more and more delegated to algorithms, machines etc. - what is the consequence for human predictions and their analysis?

Join us for a great discussion and stay abreast with some of the hottest recent topics.

Looking forward to meeting up with you,

Christian

Sources / References

Agrawal / Gans / Goldfarb, 2016: The Simple Economics of Machine Intelligence. HBR, November 2016.
https://hbr.org/2016/11/the-simple-economics-of-machine-intelligence

Agrawal / Gans / Goldfarb, 2018: Prediction Machines: The Simple Economics of Artificial Intelligence. Harvard Business review Press.

https://agrawal.ca/artificial-intelligence/

McKinsey discussion of the 2018 book:
https://www.mckinsey.com/business-functions/mckinsey-analytics/our-insights/the-economics-of-artificial-intelligence?cid=other-eml-alt-mkq-mck-oth-1805&hlkid=05aacdb5aeed4db48b69b49af1cca72e&hctky=9613815&hdpid=146ad5fb-68c8-4fbc-8df5-b0834af6bcbf

Reference and Description in Amazon: https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/1633695670/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Kahneman / Tversky, 1973: On the psychology of prediction. Psychological Review 80(4):[masked]. http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.395.3759&rep=rep1&type=pdf

Nate Silver: The Signal and the Noise. The Art and Science of Prediction. New York: Penguin Press.
